As a human rights lawyer, I deal with emotionally heavy cases on a daily basis. The stress and pressure often lead me to overeat, especially during high-profile cases. I find myself snacking constantly during long nights of case preparation, and I often skip proper meals only to binge eat later. The recent setback in a major case has intensified this pattern. I know I'm using food to cope with the emotional toll of my work, but I feel powerless to stop. I've gained weight and I'm too tired to go running, which used to be my stress relief. Working as a nurse practitioner, especially during night shifts, has really taken a toll on my eating habits. I find myself constantly snacking to stay awake during long shifts, and then overeating when I get home as a way to decompress. The rotating schedule makes it hard to establish any kind of routine with meals. After a recent traumatic event at work, I've been turning to food even more for comfort. I know it's not healthy, especially given my medical background, but it feels like the only thing I can control in my chaotic work environment. My husband is worried about my weight gain and the impact of stress on my health. I want to take better care of myself and set a good example for my patients, but I'm struggling to find healthier ways to cope with the demands and emotional toll of my job.
